Either impriſon'd, ſhould at laſt be freed.
If either Plot, or Ranſome, might but be
A means, whereby, the Captive might be free.
But then.—

sp.speaker: Selan.
sp.l: —A noiſe of Arms invades mine ear,

sp.speaker: Uxama.
sp.l: Your Vertues guard you, and you need not fear.
You may the god of War himſelf defie,
He muſt reſign to Loves Artilery.
Where ere you look, you conquer by ſurpriſe,
Conqueſt ſtill waits on thoſe victorious eyes.
Caeſar did take his Motto ſure from you,
Who where he came or lookt, did ſtill ſubdue.
Thoſe glances like the Cephalian Dart wound ſtill,
And Parthian like, whil'ſt you do flye, you kill,
Caeſar and Pompey are ingag'd I fear,
And by the Noiſe, their Armyes ſhould be near.
Pleaſe you wee'l walk awhile within the Grove,
And there diſcourſe the Adventures of our Love.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Uxama leading Selania as into the Grove.
The Scene is the appearance of an Army.
The Armyes fight o're the Stage, Pompey retreats.
Enter Pompey haſtily his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.l: Have I in War, as many actions done,
As that proud Eaſtern Conqueror the Sun,
Of Fortune rather then of Macedon!
The amazed World fill'd with aſtoniſhment,
Made haughty Nations tremble, where I went!
Took Mithridates King of Pontus! More
The Iberians never conquer'd yet before.
Beat the Albanians twice! to the great Sea,
The Roman Empire ſpread in Lyhia!
Spain to the Atlantick, and Albania,
To th' utmoſt limits of the Hircanian Sea!
Triumph'd ſo late, and am I beat ſo ſoon?
A Prodigy the Sun ſhould ſet at Noon.
Have I Victorious been abroad, that now,
At home, I ſhould receive my overthrow?

div.stage: Enter one of his Generals haſtily, his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Pompey.
sp.l: How ſtands our Army?—

sp.speaker: General.
sp.l: —Sir prepar'd to flye,
If you think fit, or elſe reſolv'd to dye.
The field is overſpread with ſlaughter'd men,
And bloody conqueſt dos incline to them.
Reſolve ſome courſe, before it be too late.

sp.speaker: Pompey.
sp.l: Wee'l head our men again, and try our fate.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.l: 'Twere not couragious, but 'twere deſperate.
Fly to your Army, which dos now remain
Under your valiant Generals Sir in Spain.
Fighting ſuch Odds, 'tis Juſt as if you came,
And with one Bucket ſought to quench a flame.
The game of War, ſhould not be play'd, nor ſet
Upon the odds, but on an even bett.

sp.speaker: Pompey.
sp.l: True valour never thinks on odds, but knows,
In War there is a chaunce and boldly throws.
Let's to the field again, and ſomething do,
Both for our honour, and our Countrey too.

div.stage: The Scene is the former Grove.
Enter Uxama leading Selania. Aſtragia and her Siſter. Parmeno ſervant to Uxama.

sp.speaker: Ʋxama.
sp.l: Prithee go on Selania to relate,
The manner of the Shipwrack, and your fate.

sp.speaker: Selan.
sp.l: The Winds began to roar, and Tempeſts now,
Do plough deep furrows on the Oceans Brow.
The diſmal Clouds do curtain up the Skies.
And maſque the guides of Heaven from our Eyes.
No light appears, but when the Thunder comes,
And Midwifes Lightning from the Cloud dark Wombs.
One in our Barque (as if Seas could not) tries
To drown himſelf in Waters from his Eyes.
Such were his ſighing accents, that the Wind,
Did ſeem a Calm, to th' Tempeſts in his Mind.
We all expecting to be caſt away,
The generous youth ſtood up, and thus did ſay.
Vouchſafe to hear yee gods of Cicily,
If to thoſe Vows, my lover conſtant be,
Safely conduct this Barque unto the Shore,
But if grown falſe, I humbly do implore
That I may periſh here, and that the Waves
May ſwallow me, into their liquid Graves.
Juſt now out Ship was wrackt, and each one ſtrives,
Upon the floating Planks to ſave their Lives,
The Sea was calm'd and winds do blow no more,
But what might ſerve, to drive the Planks on ſhore.
This Lady and my Self had both deſign'd,
For the Italian Coaſt, the Heavens prov'd kind,
And to the wiſht for ſhore, our Plank conveigh,
But ſure the youth did periſh in the Sea.

sp.speaker: Parmeno.
sp.l: Madam! I'm glad that after ſuch Diſtreſs,
You are arriv'd at ſo much happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Once the companion of your harder fate,
Your better fortune I congratulate.
And as Ʋxama dos reſtore your Joy,
So now Aſtragia dos my grief deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Aſtrag.
sp.l: Before your Lovers, I your love prefer,
If that by your example I do err,
It is but Juſt you ſhould the fault excuſe.
Since that his love, for yours, I do refuſe.
And may you now in him as happy prove,
As dos Aſtragia in her Siſters Love.

sp.speaker: Ʋxam.
sp.l: Things gain'd with eaſe, we do contemn; but priſe
Thoſe bleſſings which from dangers do ariſe.
Love like to Conqueſt, ſhould be pris'd the more,
If that through dangers, it was ſought before,
Since our adventures then were dangerous,
Let it be ſaid none lov'd ſo well as us.

div.stage: Enter three or four Souldiers as flying.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: — Plunder I'faith.

sp.speaker: Uxama.
sp.l: — Pray Ladyes do not fear,
Theſe Cow-hearts flye the field to meet death here.

div.stage: They fight. Uxama is taken, they ſieze the Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Search Ages paſt and Records for their fate,
The fair have ſeldome proved fortunate.

div.stage: Enter Julius Caeſar, Valerius, Curio and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: What Fugitives are theſe? that thus preſume
To Captive others, when Death waits on them?
sp.stage: They are ſeized by Caeſar's Souldiers.
sp.l: The Day was bloody, Curio! Pompey fought,
And the Victorious Lawrels bravely ſought.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: He fought with Reſolution Sir 'tis true.
But the Victorious Lawrels are your due.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: Conqueſt while in equal Ballance ſtood,
And War took equal tribute from our blood.

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: The Scale of Conqueſt which ſtood ballanc'd thus,
Being by your valour turn'd, inclin'd to us.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: What can withſtand your Power? when Eagles flye,
All Birds of leſſer prey, muſt quit the Skie.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I do ſuppoſe to Spain that Pompey's fled,
Since by Afranius there his Troops are led.
With dreadful Enſigns I will march to Spain,
And though his Armys joyn, the War maintain.
The Gates of Janus now muſt open lye,
And ne're ſhall ſhut till death dos cloſe his Eye.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: March on great Caeſar till your Arms controul,
As far as th' Artick and Antartick Pole,

sp.speaker: Curio.
sp.l: And plant the Trophies of Victorious Arms,
By Sea and Land where ever Titan warms.

div.stage: They are going off, Selania to Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Selan.
sp.l: Vouchſafe for to accept our thanks as due,
Since we all had our freedoms Sir from you.
Though we confeſs our Obligation's more,
Then thanks can pay, and gratitude's too poor.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: In freeing you I have more honour gain'd,
Then in the field, though conqueſt I obtain'd.
To this dayes fortune I aſcribe far more,
Than to thoſe many fields I fought before.
Glory in this chiefly redounds to me,
Not that I Pompey beat, but ſet you free.

l.hi: IF at a Feaſt, You ſhould not chance to lite
Upon one Diſh, unto Your Appetite,
You would condemn the Cook; juſt ſo You'l ſay,
If not one Act prove good, throughout the Play.
I Vow I did deſign to have good Cheer,
Since You are like to pay for what is here,
Which if rejected, or approv'd but Courſe,

lg.l: I'm ſure the Stationer will fare the worſe.

l.hi: But if the Entertainment You approve,
He humbly beggs ſome token of Your Love.
The Poet, if the Play no favour meet,
Reſolves for to do Pennance, in each Sheet;
And will preſume no more to be in Print,
Since His firſt Coyn miſcarry'd in the Mint.
Your Kind Acceptance may prevent My fate,
'Tis the Kings Stamp, that gives the Mettal Rate.
The Rate's inhaunc't, and 'tis made Currant too,
So ſhall this Play, if it be ſtampt by You.
